content.question: In an experiment, a disk of known rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>rotates as a result of a known force that is applied to the disk’s edge. The angular velocity of the disk is measured as a function of time, as shown in the graph. Students must determine the relationship between the magnitude of the change in angular momentum of the disk from <math alttext="t equals 0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the torque applied to the disk. What quantity could the students measure in order to make the determination? Justify your selection.

choices.label: the radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk, because <math alttext="tau equals F r sine theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>F</mi><mi>r</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>θ</mi></mrow></math>
The acceleration of a point on the disk, because <math alttext="F equals m a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

The mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk, because <math alttext="I equals one half m r squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
The direction of the rotation, because a change in angular momentum is a vector quantity

content.answer: the radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk, because <math alttext="tau equals F r sine theta" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>F</mi><mi>r</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>θ</mi></mrow></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
